title: Francesco Gessi
text:
Francesco Gessi (20 January 1588 – 1649) was an Italian painter of the <a href="Baroque">Baroque</a> period, active mainly in <a href="Bologna">Bologna</a>.
Biography.
Born to a noble family, his father noticed his attraction to the arts and placed him in the apprenticeship with <a href="Denys%20Calvaert">Denys Calvaert</a>. This did not last, since he apparently disturbed the other pupils. He was more successful under the tutelage of <a href="Guido%20Reni">Guido Reni</a>.
From there, he obtained commissions to fresco in <a href="Ravenna">Ravenna</a>, <a href="Mantua">Mantua</a>, and also the "Capella del Tesoro" in the <a href="Naples%20Cathedral">Naples Cathedral</a>. Supposedly <a href="Guido%20Reni">Guido Reni</a> turned down the Neapolitan commission after being threatened by <a href="Belisario%20Corenzio">Belisario Corenzio</a> and others. Gessi took up the work, but two of his pupils, <a href="Lorenzo%20Menini">Lorenzo Menini</a> and <a href="Giovanni%20Battista%20Ruggieri">Giovanni Battista Ruggieri</a>, disappeared. Gessi ultimately desisted from attempting to complete the latter in the dangerously competitive art world of Naples.
Returning to Bologna, he began a campaign against his former patron, Reni, attempting to compete and dismissing Reni's achievements. He was able to establish a prolific studio in Bologna. His main collaborator from the studio of Reni was <a href="Giovanni%20Giacomo%20Sementi">Giovanni Giacomo Sementi</a>, and among his pupils were <a href="Giovanni%20Battista%20Ruggieri">Giovanni Battista Ruggieri</a> and his brother <a href="Ercolino%20Ruggiero">Ercolino Ruggiero</a>, <a href="Giacomo%20Castellini">Giacomo Castellini</a>, <a href="Francesco%20Correggio">Francesco Correggio</a>, and <a href="Giulio%20Trogli">Giulio Trogli</a>.
